dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna is brooding, angry and upset. Joe steals a glance a her-

dialogues.speaker: "JOE
dialogues.text: I meant that before. You're really good. Singing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Especially since I- like- I never heard of you or anything. Donna gives him a look-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You watch sports? JOE (shrugs) Basketball-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: There must be basketball players who are really good that you've never heard of. Joe thinks for a moment-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If they're professionals and they're really good everybody has heard of them.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Well singing is different. It's a matter of taste. And-- luck. Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh. Indicates her lit cigarette-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You mind if I smoke?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No- go ahead. Joe looks at her again. She is fighting not to cry-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Couldn't be better.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Your boyfriend was the guy with the band? Randy whatsit?  10 6/4/98 14.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Mason.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I never heard of him either.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Good. A silence- DONNA (points) Stop here. Joe looks out at a funky little house-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This is it? Donna is already out of the truck-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RECEPTION
dialogues.text: We see GLASSES being tapped with silverware, then TILT to Albright standing with glass in hand, making a toast-

dialogues.speaker: ALBRIGHT
dialogues.text: When we came up to this country fifteen years ago, Margie was eight years old and convinced that we would all be eaten by grizzlies. Laughter-

dialogues.speaker: ALBRIGHT
dialogues.text: I'd like to say that so far none of us has lost anything other than the occasional backpack to the bears- and that this has been for us, like for so many other people before, a land of opportunity. A land where-

dialogues.speaker: EXT RANDY MASON'S HOUSE 10
dialogues.text: Donna steps out of the house, lugging too big a load of clothing and appliances. She dumps them on the ground, he ack in-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: There's just a couple more things. Joe jumps out of the pickup to help-  11 12 13 6/4/98 15.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I thought this was your house?

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE 11
dialogues.text: Joe enters the living room, concerned, to find Donna alre rolling up an Indian rug. Other things have been piled in one section of the room-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: See if he can survive without the fucking microwave-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're taking his stuff?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: My stuff. My daughter's stuff.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Look around you- you see ‘everything that looks like shit?- That looks like somebody with no taste and ‘bad personal hygiene would have it in their house? That's his stuff. The rest of it is out of here. Grab the other end- Joe obediently helps with the rug-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How long did you live here?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RECEPTION 12
dialogues.text: We start on the WEDDING CAKE, about to be cut. The cake i in the shape of a multi-storied cruise ship, with 'Ss MATRIMONY' printed on the side and lots of candied lifebo and other details adorning it. A plastic bride and groom stand at the top of the candy gangplank-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The actual BRIDE and GROOM pose with the knife poised, smiling as CAMERAS FLASH!

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE 13
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Joe and Donna as they load household items from front lawn onto the pickup-  6/4/98 16.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I used to gig with him when I was working in Spokane- he had this anorexic girl singer who'd get too shaky to go on stage, so I'd fill in. My booker talks me into a year up here, the money's real good, blah blah blah, and I run into Randy in Sitka and we hit it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So you move in.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No- I tell him keep your distance, I got a kid, I'm older than you, I don't smoke as much dope as you, don't think I'm moving in or anything. A pause as they continue to load-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So how does your stuff end up in his place? Donna considers the answer-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Unforeseen circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh. Donna turns her attention on him, wanting to get off the defensive-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You married?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Live with somebody?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No. She gives him a suspicious look- ._ JOE (shrugs) Sorry. Donna looks at the house-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Ten years ago I would have trashed the place.  14 Joe lifts 6/4/98 17.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That would be a bad idea. DONNA (ironic) I was still dealing with my anger.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Anger at who? DONNA . At whatever jerk I was leaving te years ago.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. up an ironing board and iron-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I told him he was gonna get bored, I told him he was gonna get itchy and start chasing little club girls, I told him my kid was gonna get on his nerves. I was right on every fucking count.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So why'd you move in?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He said he thought he was a better person when he was with me. She tosses something into the pickup-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How can you turn that down?

dialogues.speaker: EXT RECEPTION
dialogues.text: Guests are up and mingling, a few dancing to the BAND. Noelle and STACY, another teenager on the staff, move thr collecting plates-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: The guy is a climber.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: A social climber? » STACY Rock climber. You know- mountains, glaciers, whatever you can fall off of and break your neck. The best man and all his friends work up at Denali, guiding climbs for tourists.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I don't like heights.  15 16 6/4/98 18. Stacy's attention has gone to the band-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: What happened to the singer?

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROAD
dialogues.text: Joe's truck rolls into the outskirts of Port Henry-

dialogues.speaker: INT TRUCK . 16
dialogues.text: Donna is watching Joe as he drives-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You work for those two? Franny and Zooey?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Frankie and Lou. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Couple months. They're just starting out up -here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Didn't think they had any men working for them.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm one of the few.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Do they hit on the girls they hire?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No. Don't think so. They're a- you know. A couple. Donna nods, thinking-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So what'd you do before this?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pulp mill. Till it closed.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How was that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How you think it was? It's a pulp mill.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: And before?  17 6/4/98 19.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This and that, like most people.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Trapping beavers and stuff- JOE (smiles) No-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Fisherman?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I was.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You like it?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: While it lasted.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You don't go out anymore-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Why not? Joe takes a moment before he answers-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Unforeseen circumstances. They drive in silence-

dialogues.speaker: EXT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: In the REFLECTION in a window we see Joe's truck pull up front of the GOLDEN NUGGET. Next to the reflection is a promo card with Donna's photo and 'Donna de Angelo - Appearing Nitely (2 Drink Minimum)' printed on it-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Donna get out of the truck-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I should get back.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If you just help me get it off the truck, the guys inside can take over-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You gonna stay here? 17  18 6/4/98 20. The Golden Nugget is the bar on the ground floor of an ol

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We did before. This is my regular gig for the next month or so. Two shows a night.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'll come see you. Sing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Great. She watches as Joe pulls a bedside table off the back- DONNA (moodily) My kid is gonna kill me.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PARTY GROUNDS
dialogues.text: The reception is breaking up, guests leaving on all sides

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle, dressed in her street clothes now, stares at something-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: We shoot over her shoulder as she watches RANDY flirting one of the MAIDS OF HONOR behind the bandstand-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: She turns, troubled, and we FOLLOW her toward the parking lot. She passes Frankie and Lou, doing a party post-morte as they help clean up-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: It went fine-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: They didn't like the ratatouille.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: A lot of people don't eat eggplant. Like me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: You don't,.eat vegetables, Louise, and don't tell me french fries. I'm talking about normal people. Lou (0.S.) ‘It went fine. Hey, the father wanted to cater it on his cruise ship till the bride put her foot down-  6/4/98 21.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We should have made more cheese balls- Noelle brings us to Joe, who is dismantling the tent-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You out of here?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Time off for good behavior.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Saw all the groom's buddies checking you out. NOELLE (a bit flattered) Right.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Bunch of preppie thugs.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You're a hard woman to please.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Catch you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noelle steps out into the vapidly-emptying parking lot. S looks very small. She looks around, not seeing what she wants to. Stacy pulls up next to her in a battered old ca rolls the window down-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Need a ride?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess I do.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Where you going? NOELLE (thinks) I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RECEPTION
dialogues.text: Joe is beginning to dismantle the portable stage the band on. He finds a stack of flyers-  21 6/4/98 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flyers are for an upcoming appearance of Randy Mason the Pipeline, featuring Donna de Angelo. There is a photo Donna in a circle-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe contemplates the picture-

dialogues.speaker: INT STACY'S CAR
dialogues.text: Stacy drives Noelle into town-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: You know what they want to bring up here? Frankie and Lou?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Alpacas.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: For sweaters?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: For hiking trips. They want. to take people out on hiking trips for a week or so and have the alpacas carry all the gear. They do it down in the Amazon or something.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: The Andes.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: The Amazon is a jungle river- they'd be too hot. It's probably the mountain range- the Andes.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Whatever. They get em up here, no way L'm cleaning their cages. ‘These are some strange people we work with.

dialogues.speaker: . NOELLE
dialogues.text: I don't know-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: We've got the lesbo trail guides running the place, we've got the human pin-cushion in the kitchen there-  22 6/4/98 23.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Rusty-

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: He looks like he took a staple-gun to his eyebrows. We got Eunice, the cashier, twenty six years old and still lives with her mother. We got the handyman there, killed two people-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: He what?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Joe Gastineau. Mr. Dark and Moody.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: He killed people?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Got em killed. Same thing.

dialogues.speaker: STACY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Took em out fishing on his boat and they both drowned. How'd you like to carry that around with you?

dialogues.speaker: EXT DOCK
dialogues.text: Joe stands on the dock by Frankie and Lou's lodge, lookin out at a seiner moving up the channel, lost in thought -

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We're gonna be fine. It's just a lot hassle starting things up.

dialogues.speaker: LOU, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's so much work-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Joe broods. We see the SILHOUETTES of Frankie and Lou through the screen window behind him-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Two more weeks, things'll be up and running, we'll take a trip. Take the tent, the Coleman, the kayaks, row out to one of the islands and just chill, okay? Like the first time we came up here- just you and me, back in the woods again.  23 6/4/98 24.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: We hear VOICES of the BAR PATRONS downstairs as Donna, cigarette in hand, surveys their stuff piled in the middl the living room. Noelle, stiff with resentment, makes tri to and from her mother's bedroom, replacing things-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. you got stuck at work. I just had to get out of there.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I'm used to getting home on my own. I just like to know where it is. Noelle throws a handful of clothes back into the laundry basket- NOELLE (pissed) Half my clothes are missing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I grabbed everything I could see-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I had a load in the dryer.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We'll get them back.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I didn't want to move over there in the first place-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I know. It was a dumb idea. I'm sorry. NOELLE (quiet) He wasn't that bad.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Compared to what?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Compared to Lyle.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He whose name must not be spoken. I made a mistake about Randy, I'm sorry. I!'11 help you move your stuff. NOELLE (mutters) You're the mistake. Donna just stares at her, hurt and angry. Noelle pointedl takes something into the bedroom. Donna waits till she wanders out again, tries to strike up a conversation-  6/4/98 25.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Your ladies did a nice job with that reception. I didn't eat, but it looked really good. Noelle ignores her, putting up door hooks-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Do you always wear that uniform or just when they're catering? Noelle leaves for the bedroom- DONNA (calling) So is the cute guy at work who likes you. the one passing the shrimp things? With the hair in his eyes? She waits. It is a long moment before Noelle comes back o She speaks in a frosty tone, not looking at her mother-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I didn't say he likes me, I said he was good-looking, and no, that's not him. That's Perry. Perry wants to be a break dancer when he grows up.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I thought that was over.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Disco hasn't made it up here yet-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh come on-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How could you think I think Perry is cute?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't know- for a high-school kid- what do I know what you like?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Right. You don't. A silence-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So are you mad at me? About Randy? NOELLE (shrugs) S'your life.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I mean did you like him?  24 25 6/4/98 26.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It's hard enough to keep their names straight- I'm supposed to like them? DONNA. Don't be that way with me. I feel like shit. I could use a little support.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: That's what therapy is for. Pause. Donna looks around at their piled belongings-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We'll have to rent the VCR again.

dialogues.speaker: INT HIGH SCHOOL
dialogues.text: A SCHOOL BELL RINGS. Noelle steps out of a throng of mill high school KIDS. She pauses by a display case-

dialogues.speaker: DISPLAY CASE
dialogues.text: We move across several athletic TROPHIES till we settle o area devoted to young Joe. We TIGHTEN on a PHOTO of him i his uniform-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Staring at the photo-

dialogues.speaker: EXT LODGE
dialogues.text: Joe does grunt work at Frankie and Lou's lodge as the wom pitch an idea to him-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We have this job for you.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: It's kind of different-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We have this ship-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Boat - Frankie gives her a look-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We have this boat-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The Raven, yeah-  6/4/98 27.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: We had the engine overhauled, put a new gillnet drum on it-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Harmon King's boat.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: It's ours now.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: And he signed his license over-to us-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: His entry permit -

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: To pay off some of the money he owes us.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: We want you to go out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Go out.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Go out and catch fish.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm not a fisherman. Frankie doesn't understand his reticence-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: But you used to be. You know what you're doing on a boat. JOE (tight) I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: So you could if you wanted to.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If I wanted to. » LOU We'll figure out some kind of percentage deal-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We don't know if this is an asset we want to keep or to sell, but with the season almost over and this license so expensive-  26 27 6/4/98 28.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You're not like tight with Harmon King, are you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not especially, no.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: If you could go down to the marina and look at it-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Check it out, tell us if there's anything you'd need to be operational-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I haven't been commercial fishing for twenty-five years.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Has it changed that much?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: More technology. But I just don't--

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: This is really terrific. You're really bailing us out on this.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: It's a matter of credibility. If we just let people walk all over us-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I have to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Think about it. Go look at the ship- the boat- figure out who you want to have on your crew-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: You think people will do that? Knowing it's Harmon's boat?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You can always get somebody.

dialogues.speaker: INT GYM
dialogues.text: We TRACK IN at Donna, furiously stepping away on a Stairmaster machine. An AEROBICS CLASS runs through its paces in the BG. Donna starts to cry. Angry at herself, s grabs her towel and wipes the tears from her face-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe and Noelle are stacking food supplies from crates ont the shelves in the walk-in pantry-  6/4/98 29.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If the temperature of the water in the stream changes a couple of degrees, if it gets slightly more or less acid, any little change, it can mean the salmon won't return there.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Where do they go?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Probably they just keep looking along the coast till--- He shrugs-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: So the whole run disappears?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's been known to happen. They're pretty much hard-wired, fish, not many options. People, though, they've got bigger brains, they can guess at the future, make decisions-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: They just do a really lousy job of it. Joe smiles-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I hate it when they're stranded out in the air and their gills are working and they have that desperate ook-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They're drowning. In air. Noelle shoots a look at Joe, watching him work-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What do you think it feels like to drown? Joe stacks a few more items before he answers-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Never had the experience.

dialogues.speaker: INT CANNERY . 28
dialogues.text: WORKERS with STEAM HOSES attack every surface of the cann blasting fish guts and grime down into the drains in the floor. “One by one they turn the STEAM OFF- .  29 30 WALCe KEevision //6/98 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see various of the work stations- sorting tables, gutt tables, canning belts- all still and quietly dripping-

dialogues.speaker: HARMON
dialogues.text: Harmon and a half-dozen workers stand looking at the quie motionless cannery as the water settles-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: That's all she wrote.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: They say the Chinese might buy it. Pack the whole thing up, ship it over-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're welcome to it. Who needs a drink?

dialogues.speaker: EXT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: We hear VOICES of the BAR PATRONS inside-

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: It is mostly LOCAL PEOPLE in here tonight, but we start w DENISE, a cruise-line employee guiding a knot of ELDERLY TOURISTS around the periphery of the bar-

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: This is the Golden Nugget Saloon, founded back in 1881 when Port Henry was the gold mining center of the Northérn Territory. Prospectors, mining engineers, fishermen and loggers would congregate here for a stiff drink and a friendly game of cards- She brings us to Harmon King, sitting with Audrey and Ric and another worker from the cannery-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: They say nobody eats canned salmon anymore-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Do you eat it?

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Why would I eat canned when I can get fresh?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: The people in Peoria are saying the exact same thing.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: That's a_hell of a fucking note. What am I gonna do? AUDREY x What am I gonna do? Think you're the only person up here out of a job? .

dialogues.speaker: DENISE AND TOURISTS
dialogues.text: Denise passes the pool tables with her charges -

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: The first legal prizefight in the territory and the only recorded bout between a domesticated wolf and a black bear were staged in this very room. The reknowned English actress Mabel Sinclair once visited Port Henry, and it was in the Golden Nugget that a fur trapper offered her a thousand dollars worth of mountain goat hides for her hand in marriage- She brings us to SMILIN JACK and X-MAN, a pair of bush pilots, shooting pool- SMILIN JACK . He's in that little Cessna of his, coming in with the wind steady and the water is like glass and he's doing the usual rap, the wilderness, the wildlife, the glaciers- trying to impress these two girls- he's still got his wheels down-

dialogues.speaker: X-MAN
dialogues.text: Shit-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Floats hit the water- WHAM! Those wheels dig in and he flips tail over head- SMACK! The Beaver is lying belly up in the channel, the two girls are unconcious and he's upside down hooked in by his belt with water pouring in from all sides-

dialogues.speaker: HARM AND FRIENDS, VIC
dialogues.text: VIC, the bartender,-is holding forth about the charter business- vic -so I drop these people off the boat- corporate executive, second-wife, two kids by the first marriage. (more)  WHITE KEVisSioON //6/98 32. vic They got heated tents, they got freeze-dried gourmet dinners, they're wearing four thousand dollars worth of Gortex- this is gonna be a bonding experience, right? Two hours they lasted, two hours before the exec gets me on the radio. and says they've had it. I gotta call ina chopper from Anchorage, air-lift em off the island before they eat each other alive-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Audrey's turn to tell a story-

dialogues.speaker: X-MAN
dialogues.text: -Snuffy's up there spotting Herring with every other bush pilot in the state, calling down to his boats in code if he spots something when WHAMMO! Head-on with some honcho in a Piper-Cub who's got his eyes down on the water too-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: -it's so cold your spit's frozen solid before it hits the ground. And the metal on the truck has that tinny sound when you slam the door- like the whole thing's gonna shatter? So this is the day Pop chooses to make his run up to Barrow-

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: No, I don't believe there have been any shootings in here recently, but the Golden Nugget has been the setting for many a desperate confrontation-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I_can't see the front of my own damn plane, this fog is so thick, and I know there's mountain peaks all around me. But the minute I try to climb above it the wind catches’ hold of me, and with the stabilizer gone-~  6/4/98 33.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Harvest the goddam resource my ass. A man goes out and he sets and he catches fish goddammit, he's not a goddam farmer. Got more regulations than Carter got liver pills, got the Russians and the Japanese out there scooping up all our crab-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe passes through, beer in hand-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Joe- Joe turns to see Smilin Jack by the pool table-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Long time no see-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Smilin Jack. What you doing down at this altitude?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Flew some medical supply salesmen in from Cordova. There's a thousand of em over at the Convention Center.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There's always something. Where you living these days?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Two steps ahead of the finance company. JOE (smiles) See you around-~ Smilin Jack watches Joe walk away. We see Donna setting u with her players beyond him-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Jumpin Joe Gastineau. Friend of. yours?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Donna is on stage, fixing her mike-  White Revision 7/6/98 34.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Hello everybody, welcome to the Golden Nugget. For you out-of-town visitors, this is not the Gay Nineties Singalong Revue, that's at the Klondike Palace on Race Street- She sees Joe sitting down, gives him a small nod-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: -so if anybody breaks into "Oh, Them Golden Slippers" during our set, you'll be escorted from the premises. Casey? CASEY, the guitar player, starts off and Donna begins to

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Watching Donna-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: We can hear Donna SINGING distantly from downstairs. Noel is arranging things in her mother's room. She catches sig of herself in the dresser mirror, pauses. She finds a pai of scissors on the dresser, picks them up. She opens them then, watching her reflection all the while, brings the p very close to her eyeball. She presses a blade hard again her cheek for a moment. She pulls it away, leans close to examine the mark it has left, frowning. She runs her fing down along the mark-

dialogues.speaker: EXT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: Later. Harmon and Audrey exit the bar, Harm a bit unstead

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Don't torture yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: I don't intend to torture myself. I intend to torture them.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: That boat was nothing but a money pit and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Fuckin she-men think they can come up here, take over the joint. People aren't gonna stand for that.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Joe Gastineau is working out there.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Biggest fuckin loser in the Southeast.  33 White Revision 7/6/98 35. We watch Harm and Audrey walk away- * HARM (orates) Welcome to America's Last Frontier-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Give it a rest, Harmon-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: -where the minute a white man gets a pot to piss in they create a new Federal agency in charge of yanking it away from him. Where mighty bureaucracies creep glacier-like across the earth, levelling everything in their path-

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET . 33
dialogues.text: We watch Donna, done with her set, making her way through audience. She stops to chat with a CUSTOMER for a moment-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sitting alone, watching her-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna looks around, finds Joe, then crosses over to stand him-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Mind if I sit?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Please- He moves a chair and Donna sits by him. He doesn't say anything at first-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Terrific.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Who do I remind you of?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Remind me: of?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Singers. People always go "You're sort of like Judy Collins, but your voice is deeper, or you're sort of like Emmylou Harris, but your hair is curlier- "  6/4/98 36.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Screamin Jay Hawkins- DONNA (smiles) Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But I think he usually wore a bone in his nose. Joe indicates the stage-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Can you make a living doing this?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Sort of. You make a living working for the lodge ladies?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sort of.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It can be nice-~ one summer I did a cruise ship in the Caribbean, got to take my daughter-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You take her with you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Pretty much, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Her father is-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Out of the picture.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That was his choice. JOE (nods) So you've sung in a lot of places.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thirty six states and the territory of Puerto. Rico.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How bout you?  6/4/98 37.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I been to Seattle a couple times, Canada along the coast- (shrugs) It's real big up here, you go a long ways without leaving the state.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Right . An awkward pause-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So you must like it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't think I'd do so well down south- you know, cities.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How come you're not married? Joe laughs at her directness-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Sorry, if you don't want to say-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no- it's probably the same reason you're not married-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Because such a high percentage of men you meet are jerks? JOE (smiles) No-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Because women are scarce and winters are long-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's true, but-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Because you're looking for someone fun to be with who understands your bullshit but is still crazy about you-

dialogues.speaker: \ JOE
dialogues.text: That's a bit much to ask for.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No it's not. She means it. There is a brief silence-  6/4/98 38.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So have you like- recorded songs?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I made a lot.of demos. I'm not exactly up here to try and be discovered. At my age--- it doesn't make a whole lot of sense- my so- called career.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why do you still do it? She struggles to give him an honest answer-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Almost every night, doesn't matter where I'm singing, which song it is- all of a sudden I'll hook into it- I'll be feeling whatever it is the song is about and I can hear my voice, feel it, I can tell that I'm putting it across--- Moments of grace.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You know what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's totally selfish.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Tough to walk away from something you feel that way about.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I've put my kid through a lot- moving all the time. But when I take a straight job- bank teller, waitressing, whatever- I'm so- defeated- I don't want her to look at me.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But she thinks it's cool, you singing-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She's convinced my only purpose in life is to cause her embarrassment and pain.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Teenager-  6/4/98 39.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Another silence. Joe takes the leap-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So would you like to do- something?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Something.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's real pretty country around here, I could take you-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I-gotta warn you, there's certain things- the one with the long skinny boats and the paddles?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Kayaking-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't do that one.. Or anything where if the spike pulls out of the cliff you plunge to your death.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Climbing-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: In general, things where you wear gear instead of clothing- I don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I went out with this guy in Wisconsin, he'd take me camping? He had those rubber pants with the boots attached-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Waders-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I liked the walking around in the woods part and I was a really good sport about the rest, but I'm not really the Outward Bound type.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's good to know. What do you-- in the day, when you're not working-  6/4/98 40.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I read a lot-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Go to the gym, punish myself on the Stairmaster-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If I'm involved with a guy I make pathetic attempts to ingratiate myself, often involving cooking and cleaning activities. I listen to music-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mmmn-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: When my daughter was little I'd do stuff with her.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And you don't anymore?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No. Donna doesn't want to think about this. She tries to be cheerful-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So, if you're willing, let's work on this thing- this doing something idea. You try to think of stuff, I'll try to think of something-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Keep trying, really, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I will- The house band has tuned up and are doing somewhat impati riffs. Donna gets up-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You know where to find me. Two shows nightly.  34 EEE EEE LEN RD te AER IE NE FO 41. Donna gives him a smile and Joe watches her walk to the bandstand-

dialogues.speaker: EXT DOCK
dialogues.text: We see a huge CRUISE SHIP docked in front of town-

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: It was called 'Gold Fever'- We TILT DOWN to see BOBBY GASTINEAU, some fifteen years younger than Joe, standing on the dock as Denise leads mo elderly TOURISTS past-

dialogues.speaker: DENISE
dialogues.text: -and in 1897 the first wave of fortune-seekers swept through Port Henry on their way to Skagway, the Chilkoot Pass and the Yukon gold fields. Bobby pushes through the stream of tourists into a CU. He seems nervous, checking around to see if anybody is watch him-

dialogues.speaker: DENISE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They were desperate men, men willing to perish in search of the one Big Strike that every prospector dreamed of- Bobby moves past us out of the shot as Donna follows a CR DIRECTOR back toward the ship- *

dialogues.speaker: CRUISE DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: It could be the entire cruise, yes, or we might have you just do one leg, lay over at one of our stops, then work the next leg on a different ship-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How much time would I spend at home?

dialogues.speaker: CRUISE DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: We like to think of our vessels as a kind of home-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Not much, : huh?

dialogues.speaker: CRUISE DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: It's a nomadic lifestyle, no question about that, but the rewards are-  35 36 37 6/4/98 42.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CHANNEL
dialogues.text: There is MIST hanging over the water. We PAN with a dozen KAYAKERS in day-glo colors as they paddle across the the water, then COUNTER-PAN as they make way for Harmon King his motor skiff. Harmon kills the motor, drifts, then tos an anchor overboard. He grabs a six pack of beer, crosses his fishing gear and sits on some cushions. He carefully pushes earplugs into his ears, then turns a large BOOMBOX RADIO up full volume, a tape PLAYING country- western MUS He begins to jig for halibut-

dialogues.speaker: INT LODGE
dialogues.text: Lou is watching out the window. We hear the MUSIC, see Harmon drifting off anchor just a few hundred feet from t lodge- . LOU (calling) He's back.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's nothing we can do about it.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: He's going to make a feud out of this thing with his boat. Frankie steps in next to her, looks out-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Our boat. Doesn't he have a job?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: They shut the cannery down. Dammit, there's a law against stalking-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Stalking is on foot.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Skulking, then. There must be an anti-skulking ordinance.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: I'm starting to like that song.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL LOBBY . 37
dialogues.text: A hotel clerk runs a credit card through his machine-

dialogues.speaker: " BOBBY, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Listen, if there's any calls for me, if anybody comes by asking if I'm here-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Bobby watches the lobby to see if he's been followed-  38 6/4/98 43.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: -just say I'm not registered, okay? He turns and gives the clerk a charming smile-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm trying to surprise somebody, and I don't want the word to get around. Can you do that?

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREAM
dialogues.text: We see SALMON throwing themselves up a stream, a few corp washed up to the sides-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You get points for originality.

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND DONNA
dialogues.text: Joe and Donna stand watching the fish-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You're the first guy who's ever asked me to come and watch fish thrash around and die-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'm not complaining, it's really cool. I've seen it on TV, but in person like this- they're so beat-up looking-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They stop eating when they head in-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: My daughter did that for a while. Almost had to put an IV in her. Jeez, it's relentless, isn't it? They don't stop.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Some of them do. They wear out, give up-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'd make it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No sweat. I do this much every day at the gym.  6/4/98
JOE (smiles) I'm going to be gone a couple days. It's sort of a job, sort of a favor-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: When I get back- it'd be great to. see you again.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Donna is definitely pleased to be asked-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So what's this trip, like a polar expedition?

dialogues.speaker: INT BANK
dialogues.text: Bobby sits in a bank office with a LOAN OFFICER-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: A boat like yours, Mr. Gastineau, is an unusual property. Its value depends on its use in a certain type of business. If nobody experienced in that business is interested-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I don't want to sell it, I just want to take a mortgage-

dialogues.speaker: LOAN OFFICER
dialogues.text: In view of your past financial difficulties-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: That was in San Diego. ‘ LOAN OFFICER A poor credit rating is a poor credit rating, it follows you wherever you go-

dialogues.speaker: EXT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: Establishing shot-  eee NE

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: Harm and Audrey sit at the bar with Ricky, surrounded by REGULARS. Vic muses as he works the counter- vIC It's just out there, waitin for the chance to fuck you over.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY .
dialogues.text: You personally. vic Whoever. One second you're skimmin over the surface, not a care in the world, then one little thing goes wrong-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Like Rudy Bannister- . vic Rudy Bannister- he's up in a fiord longlining when the whole front of the glacier breaks off- it makes this wave- four, five stories high by the time it hits his boat. Gone.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Fucked.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Fucked from a height. And Stretch McCarthy-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Stretch-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Gets caught in the riptides trying to shortcut through Rimski Channel. They hit the rocks- two guys jump, two guys stay on board. “Stretch and the other guy who stood on board bought it. Could have gone the other way.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Luck. ‘VIC Luck, nothing. The ocean wanted him. Hell, I'm glad I'm not going out there anymore. It can be quick, like that deadhead Timmy Grogan hit, punched through his bow and sunk him in five minutes, or it can sneak up on you when you're not even looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRR Mee NMR VRE II OL IO 46.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Like Joe Gastineau-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Joey- fuck- if ever there's a guy had the world by the balls it's Joey. He was out haulin web by the time he was ten years old. His old man, Claude, run the Ice Maiden for Old Man Torgeson-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Till he drunk himself out. of a job.

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: This is the basketball player, right?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY _
dialogues.text: Best one that ever come out of Port Henry-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Headed for a full-jolt scholarship to some university in California, then he tears his knee up senior year. Kiss that goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Had a jump shot that'd make you weep- Donna sits at a table a couple yards away, a drink and a of pretzels laid out in front of her, eavesdropping with back to the bar- vic He gets on with one of Torgeson's crab boats up north, back when that was a fuckin gold mine, makes enough in one season to put a down-payment on this little gill-netter, the Arctic Dawn-

dialogues.speaker: HARM AND FRIENDS
dialogues.text: vic Gets a couple friends of his, Lester Pope, who used to work with his father, and this kid Oley-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Jack Johannson's little brother- vic Who'd never been out fishing, he's just like a high school buddy, played hoop with Joe. They're gonna go out with Joe and make a big score.  Revision 8/05/98 47.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MARINA
dialogues.text: We see Joe on the float, staring at something- vic (V.0O.) He gets the gill netter into the water, it floats, he's got. an entry permit for the silvers coming in from Icy Strait. We PAN to see the object of his gaze. It is the Raven, Harm's old fishing boat-

dialogues.speaker: VIC, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They get out there with the usual crowd, I was on the Cape Fox then, * and we hook into this run- we're barely moving, just throwing fish into the hold as fast as we can so we can set again.

dialogues.speaker: INT BOAT
dialogues.text: A floor panel is lifted. A FLASHLIGHT BEAM plays over the rebuilt ENGINE of the Raven-

dialogues.speaker: VIC, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Everybody's makin out, even Joe with this little gill-netter.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe examines the engine- VIC (V.O.) . By nightfall we're plugged and waitin in line to download into the tender. There's six boats in front of us, maybe eight behind, and Joe is the last one, and it's party time.

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: vic Everybody who's not unloading drops anchor and we start boat-hoppin, the beer comes out, Joe figures he's made his year and then some, he can pay off the boat, really get into | business fishing. A day like that, you feel like you're gonna live forever.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RAVEN
dialogues.text: Joe examines the drum, the net-  Revision 8/05/98 48. vic (V.0O.) Joe gets back on board his outfit, it's one, two in the morning, he and the Johannson kid go below to sleep it off and Lester racks out on deck. They figure it'll be morning before the tender gets to them. So- maybe the boat was out of the water too long, things dry up, you get cracks, maybe they were just so plugged ‘the water-line rode up where it had never been before, whatever-- Without a sound, the boat fills like a sponge and sinks.

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: Ricky reacts to the story-

dialogues.speaker: RICKY
dialogues.text: Damn- vic Joe wakes up and he's down in the cabin and it's black and he's under water, right, he's banging around, but he knows the boat and he bangs into something that gives him like a reference and he swims out through the hatch and yells loud enough to wake me up on the Cape Fox-- we fished him out okay, but other two- not a trace.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna listens-

dialogues.speaker: RICKY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lost -

dialogues.speaker: VIC, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lost his friends, lost the catch, there's no insurance on the boat, that's gone, and Joe-

dialogues.speaker: EXT RAVEN
dialogues.text: Joe stands at the helm, hands resting on the wheel, lost thought - vic (V.0.) -Joe, he's not the same guy-

dialogues.speaker: INT ROOM ABOVE SALOON
dialogues.text: We start on a pad of lined paper covered with a story Noe has written. PLOP! A drop of BLOOD falls onto it, instant soaking in.  49 50 6/4/98 49. We TILT to see Noelle, a razor blade in hand, studiously examining the underside of her upper arm, where she has m three parallel cuts into the skin. She watches the blood roll down, then drip onto the paper-

dialogues.speaker: EXT MARINA, FUEL PUMPS
dialogues.text: It is four in the morning, the float and moored boats roc gently-

dialogues.speaker: PUMP
dialogues.text: Joe stands with KOSLOW, a weathered man in his sixties, w writes out the bill as Joe pumps fuel. Beyond them his ma preps the Raven for the day's work-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Gastineau. G-a-s-t-i-n-e-a-u.

dialogues.speaker: KOSLOW
dialogues.text: Related to the Gastineau who sank the Arctic Dawn? JOE (hesitates) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: KOSLOW
dialogues.text: Whatever happened to that guy?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Just disappeared, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna comes out of the bathroom in her nightgown. She pee into the living room. Noelle is awake, sitting up in her shirt, looking out at the eerie northern light- DONNA. You can't sleep, baby?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It doesn't get dark.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's tough to get used to. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: . NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You want to talk?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I wish you did. A moment. Noelle keeps her voice flat, ungiving-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I know. Conversation over. Donna, worried, goes back to bed-

dialogues.speaker: EXT CHANNEL
dialogues.text: We hear Donna SINGING as we watch Joe at the wheel positioning the Raven to set, watch him working in tandem with his mate, hurrying back to pick the net and help cle the deck of writhing, flopping salmon. He is totally into the work, with no time to doubt himself or his abilities- INT GOLDEN NUGGET - NIGHT ~  §2 Donna FINISHES her SONG. She steps down of the stage toa fmattering of APPLAUSE. Smilin Jack raises a drink from h table-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I already got you one. Donna looks at the drink, considering-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How'd you guess?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Been keeping my eye on you. Donna sits, takes the drink-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Like your singing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: You really class up this joint.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I've played worse. Smilin Jack offers his hand-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Johannson- Donna shakes, lights up a cigarette-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I've been warned.  53 54 6/4/98 51.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: A lot of formerly-married women took flying lessons from you. SMILIN JACK (laughs) Yeah, well- a lot of formerly-married women are suing me for alimony. : I'm thinking of getting out of the bush pilot game, find something more lucrative.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Let's see- fast food service, camp counselor- SMILIN JACK (smiles) You live here?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: One year tour of the Frozen North.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Out on your own? She considers for a beat, then shuts him down gently-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No- I'm- I'm hooked up with a guy.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Musician? DONNA (shakes her head) He's a fisherman.

dialogues.speaker: EXT RAVEN
dialogues.text: Joe walks the deck of the boat at anchor, checking that everything is fine. He looks out at the water, the sky. H seems, for the first time since we've met him, to be at p

dialogues.speaker: EXT CHANNEL
dialogues.text: Harmon is on his skiff in front of the lodge, reeling something in with great effort, the RADIO BLARING-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Christ- The head of an enormous HALIBUT appears above water, Harm line taut with its weight. He reaches down for something-  55 55a

dialogues.speaker: INT LODGE
dialogues.text: Lou is watching from the lodge, a screwdriver in her hand

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Oh my. God-

dialogues.speaker: HARMON
dialogues.text: Harmon has a PISTOL in his free hand. He hauls the halibu a little further out of the water- POP! Shoots it between the eyes-

dialogues.speaker: LODGE
dialogues.text: Lou, shaken, crosses to find Frankie at a table going ove the menu-.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: He just shot a fish.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: Shot it?

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: A halibut. It was like a gangland execution. FRANKIE (considers) We could use some fresh halibut. When's Joe getting in?

dialogues.speaker: EXT STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: Bobby climbs up a long wooden stairway toward Joe's house He pauses to rest-

dialogues.speaker: EXT JOE'S HOUSE 55B
dialogues.text: A modest wooden house built into the side of a steep hill Bobby stands on the porch deck rapping on the door-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Joe? You home? Joey! He crosses to peer in a window-

dialogues.speaker: INT DINING ROOM
dialogues.text: A pretty good crowd for lunch. We start on Noelle, pausin next to the agonized face on a decorative TOTEM, then FOL as she brings four plates of fresh halibut to a table. Sh passes Bobby, seated talking to his waitress, Stacy-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But he still works here?  57 6/4/98 53.

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: On and off. He's out on a fishing boat right now.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fishing? Joe?

dialogues.speaker: STACY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Can I tell you about our specials? . Noelle brings us to the next table where Albright is entertaining a trio of INVESTORS-

dialogues.speaker: ALBRIGHT
dialogues.text: What are you buying when you get on a roller coaster? Not risk, because nobody but fringe consumers want that, but the illusion of risk- being hurled to the edge of danger but knowing you'll never have to cross it. Noelle lays the plates out--

dialogues.speaker: ALBRIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Disney's innovation was to. put those carnival rides and attractions into a story context, where you could imagine yourself a character in one of his cartoon epics as you floated through a Plaster-of-Paris jungle. The obvious next step- and this is the core of our proposal- is not bigger and better facsimiles of Nature, but Nature itself.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MARINA
dialogues.text: We see the Raven pulling into the dock-

dialogues.speaker: ALBRIGHT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Think of Alaska as one big theme park- Frankie and Lou are waiting on the float as Joe eases the gillnetter into the slip- LOU (calling) How'd we do?

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: All right. The mate jumps out to tie the boat off and Joe steps down onto the deck-

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: We caught something?  58 EE ONS OD oe EEE NE 54.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Made our limit.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKIE
dialogues.text: In three days?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They were running pretty fair-

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Oh my God- Joe hefts a huge salmon-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Kept a few out for the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: INT GOLDEN NUGGET
dialogues.text: Bobby blows into the bar flashing a confident smile at th late-night crowd. The bartender, VIC, recognizes him- vic Bobby-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jesus, look at this place. You're all right where I left you six years ago- same barstools, everything. Hey, Harmon, Audrey, lookin good- * does somebody come in and dust you once a week?

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: How's the charter racket, Bobby?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Can't complain. I'm thinking of bringing my Glacier Bay clients in here- 'See Port Henry's Wax Museum, amazingly lifelike figures posed in various stages of drunken stupor- ' (to bartender) Set up a round for these characters, Vic. (to patrons) I just come up from Baja- chitchat the clients, lay on the cerveza, go out and harrass a few whales-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: You like that?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I like not freezing my nuggets off here all winter, waitin to see who goes shacky wacky and blows their brains out first-  RE ee EN RN EIEIO 55.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You know Roscoe Karnes?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Roscoe with the voice box? He sticks his thumb against his trachea-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Drinks like this so it doesn't leak out of his windpipe?

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: Blew his brains out February.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I rest my case. Vic, I heard my brother's been coming in here-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Fuckin sellout-

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: You would have done the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: No fuckin way. Shoved a stake right into my heart- vic He's right in the corner, here, Bobby. Bobby turns and sees Joe-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Jumpin Joe. The man himself.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe sits back by the pool table, beer in hand, waiting fo Donna to come on-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, bro. Bobby stands across the pool table from Joe- JOE (cautious) Bobby- ‘BOBBY Hear they shut the pulp mill down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And the cannery.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Tough break.  6/4/98 56. JOE (shrugs) Town smells better.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: They told me you were out working for a couple of button nibblers at Harm King's old lodge-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's right. How you been? Bobby comes around, sits on the edge of the table closer Joe-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Terrific. I've been terrific. Took this National Geographic crew out to do a piece on the sea lion rookery just before I came up. Getting lots of repeat clients, computerized my navigation-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Teresa- ?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Teresa and the kids are cool, Joaquin hits kindergarten at the Montessori this year-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You got to come down some time, expand -your horizons.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Some time.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Listen, somebody said you were out fishing-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I just got back.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: What's the story? . JOE (shrugs) Frankie and Lou have a boat, gota license, they asked me to go out.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Back in the saddle again.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So to speak.  6/4/98 57.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: So things are okay with you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Can't complain. Bobby nods, sits in a chair next to Joe-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I couldn't get up for the Old Man-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No problem-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I had these people- Hollywood real estate honchos-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You couldn't make it. I didn't have a ceremony or anything. ‘Just did the paperwork and put up a headstone-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You got my check-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I called my mom, let her know-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How'd she take it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Changed the subject.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He was who he was.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Died in bed, man. I always figured he'd freeze to death in the parking lot outside some joint-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know the laundromat over. in Wrangell where you can take a shower?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The guys who come off the boats-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Two, three years ago I was in there, got my soap, got my towel- and back in the steam I see this old guy. (more)  6/4/98 58. JOE . I say to myself 'That is one beat-to- hell human being'. The guy looks up and it's the Old Man.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: He talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He said stuff. The last years- he wasn't really with the program any more. That's the last time I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The Old Salt. The Old Prospector. I_tell my clients stories about the Old Man- colorful shit, you know, the tour guide part of the job. How he lost those fingers, how he got through the quake and all the tidal waves on that tender- you've heard em all-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But the guy I was scared shitless of when I was little, nobody wants to hear about him.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Joey, I got to ask you a favor-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Have I ever asked you for anything?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I got a situation- it's a finesse thing with a client. I got to go pick him up in Skagway? I need somebody to crew for me, bring him back down.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You always run your operation on your own.  6/4/98 59.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: This is just for appearances. It's a business deal, see, and I need to impress this guy, I need to look less like a captain and more like- like-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Like an admiral. BOBBY . Exactly. It's a milk run, and since you're on the water again-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I've gone out once-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I can trust you. This deal- business deal- it's sensitive. Word can't get out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: When would we go?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Day after tomorrow. I just got to set a few things in motion-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'll see if I can get off work-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, you're saving my ass, man, I appreciate it. You and me, we're-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Practically strangers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're the Gastineau brothers, man.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Half-brothers.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Right. And awkward moment between them, then Bobby gets his seco wind- ‘BOBBY (rising) Listen, I got to run, bro- I'mona schedule here. I'm down at the South Marina- .

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The Orca Princess.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Sunday morning, seven sharp, we catch the tide- Joe watches him cross to the bar. We hear the band warmin up-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: -it'll be a blast.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Bobby lays a fifty on the counter, nods at the patrons on stools-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Water the plants again for me Vic. One more round-

dialogues.speaker: HARM
dialogues.text: Stoly on the rocks!

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Fuckin-A. Take it easy, folks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDREY
dialogues.text: See you, Bobby. They watch Bobby walk out of the bar- vic Kid always had a lot of pizazz.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good evening ladies and gentlemen-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna stands with microphone in hand, surveying the spars first-set audience-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: -I'm Donna de Angelo and this is the Golden Nugget. She sees Joe, smiles-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Joe watches from his corner-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I see some familiar faces in the audience-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Very happy to see him again- oe Meet “<  59 60 61 6/4/98 61.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Noelle sits on a stone stairway in front of a house, scho books in her lap. We hear SCHOOL KIDS yakking in the distance. She turns to peek over the stair wall-

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOL, KIDS
dialogues.text: HIGH SCHOOL KIDS gather in groups of two or more, talking before they have to go into the building. The BELL RINGS, and they start heading. for the door-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle stands, hesitates, preparing to make the plunge-

dialogues.speaker: EXT JOE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: The modest house on the side of the hill-

dialogues.speaker: INT JOE'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: Donna is checking out Joe's living room for clues as she talks to him-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There's a lot of factors. There's tide- is it with you, are you plowing into it, is it slack, where's the moon in its cycle- there's wind, which can jump around on you when you're ducking in and out of these islands- there's the size of the channel you're going through, the configuration of the bottom-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You still know all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah- as much as you can know it. It's like you spend enough time with somebody, even if you don't see them for a long while, you still recognize their moods.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Mmmn. (indicates room) This isn't what I expected.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What'd you expect?  6/4/98 62.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Some guys, they live alone, it can get--

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I had the Health Department over this morning, they sprayed the walls down. She smiles, indicates his CD collection-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You listen to a lot of different stuff. .

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's good. I mean, you see a whole wall of nothing but the Butthole Surfers-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Or Beethoven-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, that can be its own problem. And you read books-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Some.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So you're either a very nice, quiet guy who lives alone or you're a serial killer. Joe laughs-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I mean, my track record for conciously choosing men is so horrendous- if I ever hook up with somebody good it'll be pure luck. She steps to Joe, kisses him, steps back to look at him-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: But the odds have got to be in my favor by now- They kiss again, rapidly getting excited and making out standing up. They waltz over to a wall for some support, starting to breathe hard and pull at clothes till Donna wreaks for air, looking at Joe again-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Careful. I'm being careful, okay?  62 63 6/4/98

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: Okay. Me too. They resume, a little more cautious-

dialogues.speaker: INT CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: Noelle sits at her desk-

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Noelle, why don't we start with yours. Noelle? 63. 62 Noelle seems to snap out of a trance. She rises and self- consciously steps to the head of the room. She takes her story from the teacher's hand, turns:to face the class- NOELLE (softly) ‘The Water Baby. The midwife knew at first look it wasn't a normal delivery-

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A little louder, Noelle- NOELLE (speaks up a bit) 'The midwife knew at first look it wasn't a normal delivery. The newborn was cold as it struggled and gasped in her arms, wet and cold with a bluish pallor that did not change once she cleared its throat with her finger. It fought for air but did not open its mouth. The mother, sweat-soaked in her bedsheets, the father, video camera dropping away from his apprehensive face, her assistant, already on the phone to the life support unit- all seemed to move in a heavy slow- motion, as if under water. The midwife was halfway down the hall with the newborn before she noticed them- a tiny, half- moon slit below each ear, lined with a deep crimson membrane. Gills- '

dialogues.speaker: INT HALLWAY, SCHOOL
dialogues.text: 63 We TRACK with Noelle as she walks through a crowded hallw There is NO SOUND but her breathing-

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: We TRACK through the KIDS from Noelle's paranoid vantage, every glance and laugh seemingly directed at her-  64

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW 6/4/98 64. Noelle as she ducks into the GIRLS' ROOM, heading straight to the stalls. She enters, slams the door on us-

dialogues.speaker: INT JOE'S BEDROOM 64
dialogues.text: Donna and undressed. Joe lie on Joe's bed after taking love, not totally Donna is thinking, sniffing a bit and wiping her eyes. She speaks out of the blue- Joe nods, DONNA (reflective) I never slept with a drummer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Probably. It probably indicates a certain level of self-respect that I've never sunk below.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So ex-fishermen rate higher than drummers?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: There are certain kinds of fungus that rate higher than drummers. ponders-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What brings this up?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't know if my daughter is a virgin or not.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She's going out with a drummer?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No. I was just- you know- thinking.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Have you asked her?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't want to know that badly.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If I ask her if she needs new ; underwear she considers it invasive.  6/4/98

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mmmn .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She's been a major babysitter since she was thirteen, always wanted her own money, her own room-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Independent .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's good, I guess. You don't have any kids, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: But you were married?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I was twenty-seven, she was twenty- (shrugs) Bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She was too young-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I was- there's a whole decade back there that's pretty fuzzy-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Substance abuse-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Major-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Why'd you stop? Joe has to think about this-

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: I didn't have the guts to ride it all the way down. Donna files this bit of information-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's good you didn't have kids to fight over.  6/4/98 66.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Mmmmn .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: When's the last time you were involved with somebody?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bout a year ago.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Somebody from the pulp mill?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Aerobics instructor.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Not Corky-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know her?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She works at my gym. So who dumped who?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She thought I was too- downbeat.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She used that word?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Among others.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Well, she's a real sparkplug, that Corky- Donna gets up, sniffs, starts to button up to hit the str again- .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Listen, Joe, there's something I have to tell you- JOE (with trepidation) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'm allergic to wool.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh. .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Like a carpet, even if it's a blend, or in a blanket or clothes-  65 6/4/98 67.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I can get rid of whatever-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: No, you don't have to- just if you see me itching-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's not that big a deal. I already bought new sheets- in case you came over- DONNA (pleased) Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Donna considers him, the wheels turning- DONNA (quietly) Uh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL SUITE
dialogues.text: Noelle, still in her work clothes, hooks up a rented VCR the hotel TV set as Donna paces behind her, smoking, dres for her set. Their stuff is pretty much in order by now-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So maybe this is a terrible idea, you can veto it if you want-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Some guy.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: They're all very nice, right up until you say they're scum and shouldn't be allowed walking the streets-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: This will be fun- it's like a Nature thing- NOELLE (put upon) Please~

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You like him, you don't like him, whichever, you don't really have to deal with him again. It is totally my business.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Then why do I have to go on a trip?  6/4/98 68.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Consider it a favor to me. It's important he knows you're more than a rumor-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I'd rather stay a rumor.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Anyhow, you already know this guy- at least you've seen him around- you work with him- Noelle tightens, staring at her mother-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: - Joe Gastineau? Who works for- Donna feels the instant frost from her daughter-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Is there some problem with him? He seems really nice. Noelle just turns away, shaking her head. She is really upset -

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Is there something I should know? NOELLE (quietly) He's fine. Donna tries to get around and see Noelle's face. It dawns her-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He's not the guy you liked out there? Noelle? Noelle stonewalls her-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Honey, he's my age. Older. What did you think could happen? Nothing from Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Nothing did happen, did it? * NOELLE (put upon) Give me a break. Donna sits, trying to figure out how to deal with this-  66 67 6/4/98 69.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Maybe this is good, maybe it's a sign- we don't usually go for the same type guys- Noelle gives her a stifling glare-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If I had known you were interested in him, honey, I- “but I didn't know, did I? So you can be mad at me, but not too mad, okay? This is not a willful boyfriend-swiping type of thing, it's- it's something different. : Noelle settles in a chair far away from her mother, moodi looking out the window-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If you do.this for me, I'll love you forever.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Bobby is packing his suitcase. He lays a PISTOL on top of the clothes. He sits, stares at it-

dialogues.speaker: EXT MARINA
dialogues.text: Donna sits on Bobby's boat, the Orca Princess, watching J get it ready to take out-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know- I work with her. She's a nice kid. She's-- funny-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: In a morbid kind of way, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So you find her attractive?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
