dialogues.text: I never gave it much thought. She's a kid. Noelle! He waves to Noelle, who comes down the float carrying a b with her stuff for the trip- NOELLE (waves) Hey.  Donna cli Noelle. aboard- Noelle is Joe takes 6/4/98 70. DONNA (sotto voce) Am I sharing sleeping quarters with you or with her?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Up to you-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You two know each other. I'm going to get things squared away below: here- mbs into the hold, too nervous to hang with Joe and Joe can tell that Noelle is mad at him as she steps

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Some coincidence, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You like boats?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I don't know. Never been on them much.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We're just gonna cruise up north a ways, maybe see some whales, there's seals, sea lions-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: My mother hates boats. Anything you do outdoors that's fun, she hates it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: And she's allergic to wool.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah, she told me. still sulking, working hard at it-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You allergic to anything? ‘NOELLE My mother's boyfriends. this in stride. Donna pops back up between them-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's terrific down there.  6/4/98 71.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Bobby's got a nice operation going. She looks to Noelle, trying to be cheerful-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I love boats

dialogues.speaker: FLOAT
dialogues.text: Bobby looks back behind him to see if anybody is watching then turns and hurries down the float toward his boat, lugging his overnight bag and a sack full of supplies. He slows as he sees Joe on deck with Donna and Noelle. Joe s him, sees the confused look on his face-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bobby-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey, terrific, you made it-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: This is Donna de Angelo- her daughter Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Hi. Joe grabs Bobby's gear and Bobby steps aboard-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They're going to come along for the first leg of the trip. BOBBY (surprised) Oh- great, terrific- we'll go the scenic route-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I brought some extra groceries. BOBBY (recovering) Guy's been reheating beans on a hotplate for twenty years, I hate to see what he bought. You ladies can stake out your territories below while I get my charts on-line. Nice to have you aboard.  68 69 70 6/4/98 72.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WATER
dialogues.text: We watch the Orca Princess motoring out from the marina, Henry in the background-

dialogues.speaker: ON BOARD
dialogues.text: Bobby starts by the wheel, talking to the others- BOBBY (well-rehearsed) - Okay- safety lecture. Falling overboard is highly discouraged here on the Orca Princess, however if for any reason you should unintentionally enter the water, scream your lungs out and thrash around as long as is feasible. If you observe one of your shipmates taking the plunge, please do not attempt to dive in and save them. Throw one or more of the various floatable items you see around you toward the swimmer and inform your captain or your first mate- that's Joe. If the immersed party has been reasonably good company on the voyage we will come about and attempt a rescue at sea. Life preservers are located- EXT SEA - DAY - ‘VARIOUS SHOTS/COMPUTER CHARTS 69 We see the boat passing through channels, by glaciers, gr scenery, etc. The natural world is very big up here-

dialogues.speaker: EXT BOAT
dialogues.text: Under sail. Joe, Noelle and Donna sit up in the bow, eati lunch. They're all tense. Joe tries to make conversation-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The first night maybe you throw some water on your face, take your clothes off, crawl under the sheets-- it seems like minutes before they yank you out of bed again. You pick the money fish out of the web, ice em down, make another set- the second night you sleep in your boots, maybe take your jacket off, on top of the rack. The third night you might not make it below- by the end of the week you just find someplace safe to lean on and close your eyes for a few minutes. I've slept on fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like Hell. Joe shrugs, a bit embarrassed-  6/4/98 73.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: People get hooked on it.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: God knows why.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's the thing itself- you know? You go out, you find the fish, you pull em out of the ocean. You're right there with it. Everything else is like second-hand- people work in canneries, they sell real. estate, they sell t-shirts, whatever. What if you couldn't sing anymore, you had to- what- work in a record store?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: So you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: And it's dangerous, you got off on that. JOE (reflective) Yeah. I guess I did. Donna looks over to where Noelle sits, raises her voice a little-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Noelle's studying to be a nuclear physicist.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Very funny.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You could if you wanted to. You're smart enough.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She kind of gave up on math and science- ‘ NOELLE They're boring.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Almost every year she's been in a different school system. She's a really good writer.  6/4/98 74.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How would you know?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I've read your stories.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: When I was twelve- DONNA . But you still write, don't you? No response from Noelle. Bobby calls, starting to take th sails down-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Weather service says we got a gale coming down at us. We're not going to make it to the Narrows. DONNA (to Joe) Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: EXT SEA
dialogues.text: The Orca Princess plows ahead through gale winds and high seas-

dialogues.speaker: CABIN
dialogues.text: Joe and Bobby stand by the wheel, the roof zipped over th heads. Bobby is scrolling through the computer charts of islands and passageways ahead-- BOBBY (pointing) If we can put in back around here the mountains will knock down a lot of the wind-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not a great anchorage-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You been in there?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: If we stay out here we're gonna get hammered.. How's the kid?

dialogues.speaker: INT CABIN
dialogues.text: Donna sits with Noelle, who holds her head between her le DONNA. You want some water? Wash your mouth out?  73 74 6/4/98 75.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We could try another one of those pills-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: No. I'll be alright. Donna notices something on the inside of Noelle's arm-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What are these cuts?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: These-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Just cuts.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How'd they get there? Noelle shrugs indifferently, not wanting to get into it-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe I got them at work. Bobby pops down, dripping wet-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: We're gonna pull up into an inlet here and drop anchor for the night. When it calms down a little I'll throw some steaks on the grill- Noelle ducks her head again-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Oh God-

dialogues.speaker: EXT INLET
dialogues.text: The wind has abated but there is still a rolling swell. W see the Orca Princess anchored near shore in a protected inlet-

dialogues.speaker: INT GALLEY 74
dialogues.text: Donna sits watching as Bobby puts steaks in the little broiler-  6/4/98 76.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: 'Frosh Phenom Cans Thirty in Overtime Upset'. 'Soph Sensation Leads St. K Cagers to State Finals'-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He's got those scars on his knees- BOBBY . Hey, this is Jumpin Joe Gastineau we're talkin, the Houdini of the Hardwood, the Beethoven of the Bank- Shot -

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He was good?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: John Wooden sent a scout up to look at him-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's somebody I should know?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: In basketball that's like God sending the Angel Gabriel down to check out your moves. Joey graduated, they retired his number, they retired his locker, they bronzed all his old jockstraps and put them in a trophy case- JOE (entering) High school.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Hey-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Game's changed a lot since then. Now I'd just be another guy.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Right. This tofu burger thing- she likes it mealy, medium mealy, black and crispy- ?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't think she's hungry.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: When this was still a Territory, it was a hanging offense to eat anything made of bean curd-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She's picky with food-  6/4/98 77.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No meat? DONNA. No meat, no fish, no dairy-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Food Nazi. I could scrape some of the green stuff off the anchor chain, heat that up for her- :

dialogues.speaker: INT FORWARD BEDROOM 75
dialogues.text: Noelle sits on the bed, listening-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: At home, I scramble eggs in the morning, she makes me feel like a criminal.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, if your own kid can't make you feel like shit, what's the point, right?

dialogues.speaker: EXT DECK 76
dialogues.text: Bobby sits up on deck after dinner, looking out over the water, uneasy. He glances up as Joe joins him-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Listen- Joe listens to the night. Nothing but waves and breeze-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You hear anything?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I thought I heard a motor.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nobody comes back here. Bobby looks toward the companionway- BOBBY (sotto voce) We got a problem, Joe. The girls there- .

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I should have asked-  6/4/98 78.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Don't get me wrong, they're really nice, they're terrific- but this guy I'm meeting- guys, actually- Bobby doesn't want to spit it out-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: It's complicated-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I was in a situation- I invested in some real estate, it didn't come out the way I hoped- there was a cash- flow squeeze. I had these clients- they own an organic food business? I_ took em all the way up from Baja to Glacier Bay, they're high the whole time but nice, right? We got along really good, and at the end they give me a bonus- it's a pound of hash-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bobby -

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Primo stuff. They say how if I wanted to, if I was that kind of guy, pow easy it would be for me to- you now-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: So they connected me with somebody who connected me with somebody else and I brought a couple loads up the last few years. It's a piece of cake, right, and the money gets me out of a jam. It's just hash- it's not crack or heroin, it's something I might do myself, recreationally. Lots of good people do it-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Are you carrying drugs on board?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: No, I'm not Joe, and that's the problem. (more)  6/4/98 79.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: The last time up, I'm off Cape Caution, the Canadian patrol boat comes racing out at me, I get paranoid. I dump the whole batch.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Aww- BOBBY . Hundreds of thousands of dollars, I get nervous and it's fish food. Turns out they had me confused with another boat, somebody réported them running too close to a pod of humpbacks. Bobby is very shaky now-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: These guys, Joe, I don't know that much about them, but they don't fuck around. They think I sold it on the side, that I'm holding out. They arranged a meet in Baja, I got nervous again, I smelled a set-up, and I-didn't show. I come up here- my home turf- I contact them, arrange a meeting, tell them we'll work it out.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That's where we're headed?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I got it all worked out- a payment schedule, mortgage on the boat, mortgage on the house- I figure they'd rather get their money back than- these are businessmen, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I told Teresa, Joe. She left me. Took the kids, went across to Tijuana to stay with her sister. You got to help me out of this thing-

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: You bring me on board, you don't tell me shit- .  6/4/98 80.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: I can't- I can't do this alone. I need somebody to back me up- just for them to see somebody behind me, I got family, whatever. Who else can I trust? Joe doesn't answer this. He looks toward the cabin, light coming up from the galley-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: But the women- we go by Tenakee Springs first thing tomorrow, right, we drop them off. “They were gonna fly back anyway, you have the plane pick them up there. Joe continues to brood-

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Stay up here for a bit. I'll figure something out to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: You're saving my ass on this, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You don't deserve it. Joe heads for the cabin. Bobby listens to the night-

dialogues.speaker: INT FORWARD BEDROOM 77
dialogues.text: Donna and Noelle arrange things so they can fit in the be

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Why don't you go in with him?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I feel funny-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Cause of me?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I just feel funny. » NOELLE Not as funny as I'm gonna feel sleeping in the same bed with you.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You used to all the time. It wasn't that long ago.  6/4/98 81.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It was that long ago. It was in another lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It could be kind of fun-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Look, if we weren't trying to impress some guy we wouldn't even be here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What do you mean 'we'?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You know what I mean-

dialogues.speaker: JOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: There's no room, but come on in if you want. Joe opens the door and looks in- JOE (to Noelle) How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: A little better.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The wind's coming down, so it should be pretty calm tonight. Tomorrow we're going to swing over to Tenakee, drop you off there- DONNA (hearing) What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's this little town with a- DONNA (pointing) No, that- upstairs- Joe turns and they hear VOICES, raised and angry-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Somebody came on board?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No-- POP! A GUNSHOT rings out and Joe immediately pushes into little room, shutting the door behind him- :  78 79 80 81 6/4/98 82.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What's happening? POP! POP! Two more shots!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Follow me! Just- whatever happens, follow me- He is up kneeling on the bed unlatching the little square plexiglas hatch overhead-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna peeks out the door-

dialogues.speaker: LEGS
dialogues.text: A man's LEGS, not belonging to Bobby, start down the ladd from the cabin-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She shuts the door, looks to Joe, who is climbing up thro the hatch-

dialogues.speaker: EXT DECK
dialogues.text: Joe stays as low as he can, crawling out from the hatch, reaching down and grabbing Noelle to pull her up-

dialogues.speaker: INT FORWARD BEDROOM 79
dialogues.text: Donna pushes to help Noelle out, then takes Joe's arm-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're in the back here!

dialogues.speaker: EXT DECK 80
dialogues.text: Joe helps Donna through and pulls them both by the hand t the side of the bow closest to the shore-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit! They're up here! Joe pushes Noelle, then Donna, then dives- POP! POP! as more SHOTS are fired-

dialogues.speaker: EXT WATER
dialogues.text: SPLASH! Joe hits the water and comes up, finding the two women treading water-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Swim! Come on! POP! POP! POP! The three swim for shore as GUNSHOTS ring out over the black water.  82 83 6/4/98 83. About halfway to shore a FLASHLIGHT BEAM begins to play o the water, searching for them-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe reaches the shore first and helps the others up over rocks. POP! POP! Wild SHOTS are fired from the boat. Joe hurries the women into the trees. Noelle doesn't have sho

dialogues.speaker: EXT TREES
dialogues.text: Joe, Donna and Noelle move back into the thick woods, climbing awkwardly. Finally they stop, breathless, wet an shivering, supporting themselves against the bole of a fa tree. Joe immediately starts pulling his clothes off, wringing them out and laying them on the tree-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Somebody shot Bobby.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Who shot him? Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know- he told me he was in trouble, just now- I don't know how they found us- .

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Take your clothes off-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We've got to get the wet things off and huddle up together or we'll freeze. Hurry-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We have to get help!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There's nobody on this island. Help Noelle- . Noelle is shivering uncontrollably-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I'm cold. Donna bends to help take Noelle's clothes off-  84 6/4/98 84.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If they come after us we're going to have to move, so put your shoes back on-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I don't have any-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I don't believe this. This can't be fucking happening- They get the last of Noelle's clothes off. Joe wrings the out and lays them out on the tree. Donna lifts Noelle in arms, hugging her close. Joe puts his arms around both, sandwiching Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The night doesn't last too long this time of year. We're gonna be alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the three people crouching, huddled together up against the tree-

dialogues.speaker: EXT INLET
dialogues.text: The Orca Princess sits anchored in the early morning mist water calm now. A CHARTER BOAT is anchored beyond it. We see two MEN stepping down into a little SKIFF. We SHIFT t see that we are looking over the shoulder of Joe, crouchi behind a tree-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: Joe, wearing only underpants and shoes, creeps back into woods -

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: Joe returns to the fallen log to find Donna and Noelle starting to dress in their damp, cold clothes. They are a drawn and shivering-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They're coming in. They all turn as the WHINE of SKIFF MOTOR starts up. Joe goes to one knee- JOE (to Noelle) Hop on. Noelle gets on his back and he stands, then begins to cli diagonally through the trees. Donna grabs the rest of the clothes and follows-  85 86 6/4/98 85.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE 85
dialogues.text: The prow of the skiff bumps the little beach. LEGS appear the MEN drag it ashore-

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: Shots of the men, separately and together, searching thro the woods. We never see above their waists. One carries a handgun, the other a hunting rifle-

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: The legs of one of the men pass through the frame. We HOL then TRACK IN till we see Noelle, terrified, lying under fallen branch, trying not to shake-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.8S.)
dialogues.text: Hey-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: This sucks. I've had it with this shit.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: One more sweep.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fuckin mosquitos eatin me alive- Noelle closes her eyes. The man, turning back, steps only inches from her face-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE 2, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Let's go back a different way than we came.

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: We see the SUN high in the sky, framed by TREETOPS. We TI DOWN to see Donna and Noelle sunning in an open patch, looking beat. They have staked out some of their clothes sticks to dry better. Joe steps into the clearing, kneels them-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The boats are gone. He sits and pulls off his shoes and socks-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You think they'11 come back?  6/4/98 86.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No way to know. Listen, I'm sorry-- I had no idea till last night that something was wrong-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You think they killed him?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Little inlet on the backside of Kuleshov Island-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: And that's like up Shit Creek without a paddle?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pretty much. I figure we should head around toward the channel while it's still light, hope we run into a stream. We'll be okay without food for awhile, but water- He wads a sock into the toe of one of his shoes and hands to Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Try this.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What are you going to use?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'll be careful where I step. Go ahead. Noelle sticks her foot into the shoe, starts to lace it u Donna holds her head in her hands-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: This is not happening to us. This is only a dramatization of somebody else's pathetic story.

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: It could be worse. It's not so cold yet- I've got my knife- Donna digs in her pocket and produces her cigarette light

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We can have a fire tonight.  87 88 89 6/4/98 87. Joe takes the lighter, rolls it in his fingers-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know-- the smoke. They might not be too far.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna let her freeze like that. Not again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: Joe, Donna and Noelle walking through the woods, the wate visible just down the slope beyond them. Noelle has Joe's shoes on. Joe steps carefully, watching the ground-

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: A stream a few yards wide runs down the side of the hill. PAN, following the current, till we come to Joe and Noell their knees, drinking-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's a place to cross down here! Joe stands and we FOLLOW him down to where Donna stands a the foot of a rotted plank-and-rock bridge spanning the stream-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We don't have to get wet again. Joe kneels to examine a rotted plank-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: These have been milled.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: People made this thing, right?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: Overgrown, falling down PENS stand under the trees, bits wire and wood tangling as the walls sag this way and that We PAN to see Joe and Donna checking it out-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: People used to raise foxes- for the pelts. It was a big deal for awhile.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Why come out here?  90 91 6/4/98 88.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Land was available, I guess. People would hunt, fish, try to grow some things-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Over here!

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle stands at the edge of an overgrown clearing, stari at something. Donna and Joe appear behind her, seeing-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: We shoot past Noelle toward a falling down wreck of a HOU roof caved in, debris scattered on and around the rotted- through porch. Weedy trees have grown up all around the fireplace and chimney, which are Still standing-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Somebody lived here.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE
dialogues.text: We see FLAME through the boards and sections of roofing t have been fashioned into a kind of lean-to, anchored by t fireplace-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE 91
dialogues.text: A FIRE of sticks and splintered wood laid in an old washt smokes and CRACKLES. Noelle sits as close to the fire as she can while Donna fans the smoke away with a shingle. J has his knife out and is trying to make a pair of sandals from piece of ruined carpet. The interior of the house is chaos of gutted furniture and sagging walls. Donna coughs from the smoke- DONNA. Tomorrow they'll miss us. Noelle won't be in class-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Nobody'11 miss me in school.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: They'11 miss you at your job. And Joe. And.I'm supposed to sing at the Nugget.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Be a few days before anybody's likely to start calling around for us. Bobby wasn't keeping radio contact, nobody knows he cut over this way.  6/4/98 89.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How long does it take you to starve? Joe glances at Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know- depends on what shape you're in, what else you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Remember I did that fast when we were in Idaho? How many days was that?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You cheated.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I did not. I had some tomato juice-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Then it isn't a fast. DONNA. Well I'm starving now. How far do we have to walk?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Couple days, maybe more- DONNA (dismayed) Days-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I think we should hang here where we've got some shelter for a while, make sure those guys don't come back, then make a signal fire on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: People come in here to fish?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No. Nobody does anything on Kuleshov. Donna looks around the ruined interior-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Except the lunatics who built this place.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe scrapes mussels off the rocks with his knife as Donna wades thigh deep in the water, pulling up seaweed-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How bout this stuff?  93 94 95 6/4/98 90.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Just take that batch you've got and rinse it in the stream. She heads for a pile of darker green seaweed left on a ro

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We gonna make that signal fire? Joe looks out at the inlet-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I think we can risk it tomorrow. We find a spot that doesn't go under when the tide is in.

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE 93
dialogues.text: Noelle steps out with an armful of trash that she tosses the side of the house. She heads back in-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE 94
dialogues.text: Still a mess but they've cleared more space for themselve the solid part of the floor. We FOLLOW Noelle to a sodden mass of rags and papers, stuffed into the fireplace, that begins to toss wad by wad onto a section of carpet. She pauses, coming up with a small, leather-bound book with a clasp on it. “She undoes the clasp. The pages are damp bu still intact- NOELLE (reading) 'My Diary- | She looks around, crosses to a spot on the floor where li is slanting in from a hole in the roof, sits and begins t read-

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Joe knife slices into a dull purple sea cucumber, a long, turd-like creature, cutting it into strips-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We gonna eat that thing too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noelle and Donna sit on sections of the ruined porch, che on mussels and washing them down with stream water from a battered metal pan. Joe is butchering the sea cucumber on plank-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sea cucumber. Lots of protein.  96 97 98 6/4/98 91.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Right . (to Noelle) Pass me some of that algae-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Kelp.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Kelp. These mussels are like rubber.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Frankie steams them in white wine with ginger. Donna gives her a look- NOELLE (shrugs) On a bed of saffron couscous. It's one of the appetizers. I memorized them.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If we're here for a while I'll rig something up for cooking. Donna makes a bitter face and coughs out something green-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Sorry. He hands Noelle a small piece of the sea cucumber-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Chew this, really slow-

dialogues.speaker: EXT INLET
dialogues.text: Ripples in the water-

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: The trees stir slightly with the breeze-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Noelle's face is lit by FLAME as she reads- NOELLE (reading) "My name is Anne Marie Hoak, and this is my diary."

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND DONNA
dialogues.text: doe and Donna sit on the floor on the other side of the s basin fire from Noelle, listening-  6/4/98 NOELLE (reading, 0.S.) "Papa and Mother and I have come here to make a go at the fox farming trade. If this pans out, says Papa, "-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: NOELLE (reading) "-next year I can go back to finish with school. I offered to get on at the cannery to help out when we were in town, but Papa says there is too much trash working there. He was a logger but fell while he was topping and now has headaches and dizziness that prevent him from many of the trades other men pursue. This way, he says, we can live in the Great Outdoors and operate our own business at the same time, which is every man's true desire. Mother doesn't care for it."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NOELLE (reading) "We have transported a dozen breeding pairs of the blue-pelt foxes and put them in their pens. They are lovely to look at but nervous and I need to mind my fingers when I am near them. When the vixens are ready to bear we will separate them to be alone with their litter. Papa is building a fish trap in the stream, as he hopes to catch the returning chum for fox- food. I expect it will be a hard life, but work is scarce back in town and Papa's spirits were getting low. The people who built our little house tried to make it fishing and rowing out for stray logs to sell back to the mill, but they gave up after a few seasons. Mother goes on about how she will miss female company and that I will have to be her special friend. I know that Papa thinks he has been a disappointment to her, and sometimes she doesn't do much to hide it. I will be lonely here, I can tell, but it should be a great adventure, like Caddie in Caddie Woodlawn. I will try to be a aithful writer, Dear Diary, and tell you my innermost thoughts." Noelle puts the diary in her lap looks at them-  Revision 8/05/98 93.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Wow. Read some more.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We may not be here tomorrow. NOELLE . I found it. I'11 read it when I want to. They stare at each other for a moment. Neither blinks-.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We'll have something to look forward to. Like a soap opera.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Whoah. It sounds like we're moving in-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There's no telling how long it's going to be.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Wonderful. She looks at Noelle, at the ruin around her, fighting bac tears-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We're going to be alright, aren't we? We're gonna be fine. Nobody seconds her. The fire crackles-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SEA
dialogues.text: We slowly FADE IN from complete BLACKNESS to see the surf of the sea at night. WHOOSH! Joe, younger, bursts to the surface, gasping to fill his lungs with air. He treads water, looking about frantically, then calling-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Lester! Oley! Nothing. We drift around to see a FISHING BOAT, the Cape Fox, anchored thirty yards away-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey! Somebody! Help! Help me! It is Vic, younger, who raises his head over the side of boat. He is drunk and sleepy-
vic * Who the fuck is that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: They're on the boat! Lester and Oley! Vic stands unsteadily, looks past Joe, puzzled- *

dialogues.speaker: VIC
dialogues.text: What boat?

dialogues.speaker: CU JOE
dialogues.text: Joe treads, circling. No sign of his boat or his friends. He takes a deep breath, dives under. BLACKNESS-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Joe wakes with a gasp, as if he's been holding his breath Donna wakes beside him. All three are sleeping around the embers of the fire-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah- Donna looks over to Noelle, still sleeping,. huddled up against her under Joe's jacket-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: All I want is for her to be happy and safe. She's not either. Joe disentangles himself from them, squats to feed the fi

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: People must have always smelled like smoke. She watches Joe for a long moment-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What's the matter? He doesn't answer, brooding-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What? JOE . You can't always save people. They exchange a look, then Joe moves to cover Noelle's fe eM ta  101 6/4/98 95.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Noelle struggles to drag driftwood across the rocks. We P to see Joe and Donna piling wood and trash from the house the edge of the woods- .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe lights a stick with some dry moss wrapped around it w Donna's lighter. Noelle arrives and lays the wood down. J lights several sections of the pile. It begins to smoke, then flames start up-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We need to feed this a couple times a day. When the sky's like this it won't be easy to spot, but on a clear day-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What if it rains?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It rains, or the tide comes in too high, we'll probably have to start from scratch.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: And we hope somebody sees this and wonders what the story is.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Somebody who doesn't want to kill us. Donna gives Noelle a hard look-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's a possibility.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You two are a great match. Gloom and Doom.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: There's no use pretending-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Yes there is. We're camping here. Like survival school camping. This is what they mean by quality time, right? No distractions, no media stuff, we get to know each other, gnaw the bark off the trees- people pay money to go on trips like this. They are both looking at her now-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You assume that bad shit is gonna happen, bad shit happens. She roughly throws some more branches of the fire- DONNA (mutters) I don't see the point.

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: Joe is trying to make a fish-trap from pieces of the old pens as Noelle looks on-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The fish go in through here, then they can't turn around and get out. That's the idea, anyway. This wire is kind of brittle.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Where'd you learn all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: My old man taught me.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You did lots of stuff with him?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: When he had something to do and he needed somebody to swear at he took me along. Not the answer Noelle wanted to hear-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: My father's a composer. My real father.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How long did you live with him?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I didn't. She split up with him- you know- before.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: . NOELLE
dialogues.text: Bobby was your half-brother?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You ever live together?  6/4/98 97.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No. We saw each other around. He was a lot younger- different friends, different life.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I've got two half-sisters and a half- brother.

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: What are they like? NOELLE . I never met them. They're pretty little, still. I saw themina - picture- he was in People Magazine, my father.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So you don't visit?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: She doesn't want me to.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: So you write letters, phone calls- ?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: No. Joe glances at her, doesn't pursue it-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You don't think we're gonna get rescued, do you?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: We have to stay strong until somebody comes. We need to stay warm, find things to eat. Just concentrate on that. She fingers the mesh on the trap-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Think we'll catch anything?

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Diary time again. A fire in the fireplace. Each of them h some kind of improvised seat-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: "The house is small, but cozy now that we have cleaned it up and made it our own. (more)  6/4/98 98.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I have my own room, and at night I can hear the owls calling back in the woods and our foxes yipping when something wild comes by. Yesterday I saw whales feeding in the inlet, going under for awhile then bursting up through the surface with a great spouting of air and crying of gulls. There are blueberries everywhere. My fingers are stained purple with them, though Mother insists I will be attacked by bears if I stray too far from the house. Papa's headaches are better and I help him clear the fish trap and prepare the feed for the animals. It is unpleasant, sticky work, but must be done. I have gotten stronger handling the skiff and Mother chides Papa for making a boy of me, but I don't mind. The days it doesn't rain are God's glory and most of our vixens are close to giving birth. Some days I will go for hours without speaking, and feel I am changing, perhaps posessed by the soul of some long-dead Indian girl, or perhaps the spirit of a she- wolf. This morning I snuck up on Papa felling a spruce for the fireplace and watched him for a long time without him seeing me. Perhaps I shall learn to become invisible. I made blueberry pancakes. Mother says if she eats any more fish she will grow fins and swim back to town. At night she has me kneel with her to pray." Noelle lays the diary down-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Sounds like Mom's not the Wilderness Family type.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sounds like it might be in the Depression. That's what- fifty, sixty years ago-

dialogues.speaker: . DONNA
dialogues.text: You gonna read us more? Noelle considers, then opens the diary again-  104 105 106 6/4/98 99.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: "The terrible birthing has begun. We think one of the vixens has eaten her litter. The kits, the ones that survived, are lovely once their eyes open. Papa told me not to handle them but when he is off sometimes I do. Their heads are squarish and fluffy." She closes the diary and shuts the clasp with finality- DONNA (smiles) Fox babies.

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Noelle is picking her way across the tidal mud, poking in air holes with a long stick to dig out clams. We see the plume of SMOKE from the signal fire far behind her. She suddenly CRIES OUT, almost stepping on_something. She ste back, frightened, then approaches slowly. We see that it Bobby's corpse, half-buried in the mud, CRABS chewing on Noelle contemplates it for a long moment. She flicks one the crabs away with the stick. Feeling shaky, she sits on rock-

dialogues.speaker: INT WOODS
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Joe, lugging a large rock. He bends and places on a pile of similar rocks, filling up a depression in th forest floor. Donna and Noelle stand watching-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Isn't that enough?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Don't want the bears to dig him out. (to Noelle) I'm real sorry you had to see that.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Killing somebody for money-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: By the middle of the winter up here people kill each other cause they're bored. He took a risk and it didn't work out for him, that's all. He lifts up another stone, heaves it onto the pile-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: We hear Noelle read softly from the diary, her voice flat we watch Joe walking moodily along the shoreline-  6/4/98 100.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: "Winter has locked us in its icy embrace. The pelts of the animals are thick and bluish and our home is blanketed with snow. Papa calls it Limbo, because it sure isn't Heaven and it's too cold to be Hell. Mother wondered about Purgatory, but he said no, Purgatory has an end to it. Don't torture me so, said Mother.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle sits up by the treeline, crying, watching Joe in t distance-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The salmon we dried have run out. The kits are eating solid food now and it is hard to keep up with them. Papa went to the far side of the island and shot a pair of sea lions, but could only bring one back without tipping over in the skiff. I had to help him with the cross-cut saw, breaking it down to pieces that we keep frozen in the shed. Papa said it's just meat but I tried not to look at what I was doing: The other sea lion had been gotten to by a bear when Papa rowed back.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna sits by the signal fire, watching the sky-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We put a piece of the frozen meat in each of the pens and the foxes fight over it and gnaw at it and the outside melts from the heat of their little tongues. Mother won't deal with them anymore. She has grown silent with the shorter, darker days, and only now and again will she break out into one of her Bible songs. She asks me to join her, but we don't harmonize well.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Noelle reads by the fire, Joe and Donna listening in mood silence-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I have a dream about Fox. He is a young man who comes for me on snowshoes, dressed in the blue pelts. (more)  108 109 110 6/4/98 101.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: His skin and hair are dark but His eyes are ice-blue. All the others here are paired, He says, Papa and Mother, the sires and the vixens, but I am alone and He can't let that continue. Sometimes in the dream He stays with us, but usully He picks me up and carries me to His own island. Papa says if we can get the animals through the winter they are a Gold Mine. He says fortunes have been started on less. He says if he keeps having his dizziness I will have to go hunting with him the next time. The burns from where Mother hit him with the bacon grease are only pink now, healing, though the hair doesn't grow on that part of his jaw. I am sewing a sampler." She closes the diary. Donna and Joe watch the fire, think

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREAM
dialogues.text: Time has passed. Noelle, standing thigh-deep in the strea yanks the jerry-rigged fish trap to the surface. There is very large salmon caught in it, flapping desperately as i hits the air. She CRIES OUT and drops the trap, then gets her courage and hauls it up again. She smiles-

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: Joe and Donna embrace leaning up against a tree, holding tight, rocking a little, clinging like their lives depend it-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle stands back in the trees, watching mutely, the sal slung over her shoulder with a cord through its gills-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe pulls a flat stone out from the embers of the signal fire, blows the ash off it. He lays thin strips of the salmon meat on it-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You don't worry about burning it up this way-.just flip it over after a minute- We SHIFT to see Donna and Noelle. Noelle sits away from them, sulking, shivering slightly- JOE (to Noelle) You laid the trap back in?  6/4/98 102.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: . JOE
dialogues.text: Indians used to smoke everything they couldn't eat, hope that it lasted the winter. : Donna is looking at the sky-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Good day for planes.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Nobody's coming.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Don't be negative-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: In two weeks how many planes have we seen? Zero.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We heard that one.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There would have been more if they were searching for us here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Bobby may have told people at the dock we were headed in a different direction. He thought people were after him-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: People were after him-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Anyway, they may be searching in a totally different area.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Stupid-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Noelle- .

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Trying to impress your boyfriend, drag us out on a boat-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's enough.  A silence. 6/4/98 103.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It's true.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Look, I am cold, I am hungry, I am dirty, and I am scared shitless, just like you. But I'm trying to help us get through this thing- NOELLE . I shouldn't be here. I shouldn't be in this state, I shouldn't-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Nobody is to blame for this-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, right-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: When you are of age, Noelle, you are free to go fuck your own life up. Until that day, I'm afraid, it's my job to fuck it up for you! Donna looks to Joe-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You could help me with this-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: He's not my father.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Thank God for that.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Your father would have gone off picking berries or something and that's the last we'd have heard from him.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: How would you know? He was in the same room.with you maybe twice-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You wouldn't let him-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If you cross his mind once a year, max, I'd be surprised-  6/4/98 104.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Every Christmas-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh Noelle-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: He sent me a bike, he sent me a watch, he sent me a dollhouse-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: iI sent the watch! This shuts Noelle up. She had no idea. Donna isn't happy she let it out-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I sent the bike- all of it. I figured when you were little, you had Santa Claus, the Easter Bunny, you might as well have a father in California who sent you stuff. Noelle glares at her, tears in her eyes. Joe flips the salmon, hoping to stay out of the crossfire- NOELLE (muted) I hated that dollhouse.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I know, honey, but you wouldn't let me exchange it, cause it was from him. Remember? She sees that Noelle is shaking-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I'm great. I'm kickin- DONNA (moving) Let me feel your forehead- Noelle pushes her hand away-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! Donna backs off. She uses a piece of seaweed to pick up t hot stone, offers Noelle the salmon-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Eat something.  6/4/98 105.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Noelle reads solemnly, slowly. She is by the fire and wrapped in Joe's jacket, but still trembling with a fever

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: "I was the one who found them. It was time to clean the scat from the pens so I had the shovel and the buckets and then there was blood everywhere in the snow. All of them torn and smashed, even my little kits. A bear, says Papa, though when has a bear got into a half-dozen different pens without breaking the gates? Mother says nothing, but she is only a black spot these days, and refused to celebrate Christmas. The pelts are ruined, of course, worthless, and our long care is for naught. Papa couldn't speak when he saw them. He says his head hurts trying to think a way out of our dilemma. Joe shoots a look at Donna to see how she is taking this-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: I dreamed that Fox came and was angry for what we let happen, that He held me down on the snow and I felt His hot breath on my face, felt it bitter in my throat, and felt his ice-eyes cutting into me. I wish He would come soon. Mother sleeps with me now and it is cramped and tense. You would think another body under the covers would bring warmth, but I wake feeling drained, like she has pulled all the heat from me. I am doing the cooking now and my eyes are always red from the smoke. The wood is too big for the cookstove, but the axe has gone missing and we can't break it down. Mother says Hell is a cold place. Maybe I am the soul not of a she- wolf, but of a soaring bird that flies south every winter, and my heart is so sick because I am not supposed to be here in this cold, this dark, this wet. Maybe I am like the air in this house, the air that does not move when Papa and Mother pass in silence, dead, smoky air that smells of wool and old bacon. Tears begin to roll down Noelle's cheeks as she reads-  116 6/4/98 106.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: We threw the animals on the rocks for the tide to deal with. Papa cried."

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Noelle is feeding the signal fire. She hears something, stands shakily to look’up, shading her eyes-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over Noelle's shoulder we see a FLOAT PLANE flying over t other side of the inlet. Suddenly it banks and heads righ toward her-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Excited, she starts to yell-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: It's coming! It's coming!

dialogues.speaker: INT WOODS
dialogues.text: Donna is dragging fallen branches toward the shore. She hears Noelle's VOICE, drops the branches and begins to ru

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE 114
dialogues.text: Donna breaks out of the woods and begins to run toward th signal fire. Joe comes out of the woods behind her, looks the sky, then follows running-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Donna! Careful!

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle is in the FG as the float plane lands in the inlet taxis straight toward her-

dialogues.speaker: INT PLANE
dialogues.text: We see through the windshield as the shore approaches. A young girl by a fire, joined by an older woman and man-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: Noelle and Donna are beaming, Joe worried-

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: The little float plane slows as it nears the shore. Joe wades out into the water to grab hold of the float tether the engine cuts off and the prop stops turning. Smilin Ja steps out onto the float on his side-  6/4/98 107.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: You_folks picked a hell of a spot for a clambake. DONNA (stepping forward) We've been stuck here forever! We've been stranded! SMILIN JACK (looking past them) Any more of you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Just us. We were on Bobby's boat- Joe's brother? And he was- murdered. Joe shoots Donna a look. It's clear he doesn't totally tr Jack. Jack looks at Joe-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'm not sure who did it. We jumped off at night-- there were a couple fellas came in looking and we hid, then they pulled anchor- He shrugs-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Damn. How long you been here?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: A week and a half? We found what was left of an old house, we've been holing up there at night. SMILIN JACK (shakes his head) And I was hoping you people could help me. My radio's shot, I'm low on fuel and I'm heading into bad weather. JOE (suspicious) Your radio's gone?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Crapped out on me a half hour back. Not even static. He looks to the sky, looks at the water-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Tide's going out fast. I'm gonna have to turn this thing around and try to get out of here, send help-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Take my daughter, then. She's sick-  6/4/98 108. SMILIN JACK (grave) I'd love to, but I can't handle the weight. Believe me, it'll be safer here-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She barely weighs a thing-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I got to jettison whatever I can: to have a fighting chance. Sorry ladies. He pulls off his jacket, tosses it to Noelle- SMILIN JACK (to Joe) You want to give me a hand with this? He reaches in and starts tossing things-on shore-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I got a first aid kit in here- no food though-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA AND NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle is shaking again. Donna puts her arms around her, grim-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We'll have to spend one more night out here. honey, that's all. Then they'll come and get us-

dialogues.speaker: JOE AND SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Joe helps Jack wrestle the tiny plane around to face out sea. They speak quietly enough that the women can't hear-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I'm real sorry to hear about Bobby, man. I used to party with him up in Haines-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What's the story?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: What's what story?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Who sent you? Jack meets Joe's eyes for a long moment, then gives a fur look toward the shore-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donna and 6/4/98 109.

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Couple guys- Mr. Smith and Mr. Brown- never seen em before but I don't think they're up here to save the whales. They laid some serious money on me to poke around, see if I could spot three people roughing it in the boonies.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And if you saw them?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Just go back and tell them where.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why'd you land, then?

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: I'm on the level about the radio and the rest of it, Joe. I was hoping to find some sport fishermen with a short-wave and a cooler full of brew.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Noelle watch, Donna reassuring her daughter-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We'll sit in a hot bath for a day or so while people bring us everything we want to eat and drink and then we'll get into a soft bed with clean sheets and just hibernate-

dialogues.speaker: PLANE, MEN
dialogues.text: Smilin Jack gets into the pilot's seat and buckles up-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: If I'd known the deal with Bobby I'd of turned em in- you have to trust me on that.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Right. Jack leans out and calls out to the women on shore-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Hang in there, ladies! I'll be back with the cavalry tomorrow! He looks to Joe-

dialogues.speaker: SMILIN JACK
dialogues.text: Wish me luck, buddy.  6/4/98 110. Joe says nothing. Jack grins, shuts the door, gives Joe thumbs up. Joe steps off the float and moves away as Jack revs the engine and begins to taxi away-

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe joins Donna and Noelle as the plane gathers speed and takes off from the water-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We're saved. We're gonna make it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: The three sit around the fire. Joe speaks carefully, not, wanting to dishearten them, but deeply troubled. It has begun to RAIN outside-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: The last I heard he was flying out of Anchorage, kicking square halibut out - of a cargo plane-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Marijuana bales. You fly over a spot on the water, somebody signals with lights or gives you a code over the radio, and you dump your load. The people in the boat below fish the bales out and take them to the next stage.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He's'a drug dealer.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: He's whatever pays best and he can get away with. He's got balls and he's never gotten caught or bought the farm. Bad weather, bad company- you got the cash Smilin Jack's your man.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: He hit on me a couple times at the bar. He seemed like a nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I didn't say people don't like him. I said I don't trust him.  6/4/98 111.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: You think he might tell those men? And bring them back here?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I don't know. I didn't believe him about the radio- and we've got some personal history-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: His brother drowned on a fishing boat. It was my fault. Donna ponders this a moment- She turns DONNA (deciding) He wouldn't do that to us. He's not a killer.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I've looked in his eyes. TI can tell things about a person-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Like you could tell that Dwayne in Colorado Springs wasn't cheating on you with the cocktail waitress-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: This is different-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Or that Lyle would never hit you-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Once, he hit me once and I walked-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: But you didn't see it coming, did you?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: We don't have any choice! You're sick, it's getting colder, we can't stay here! to Joe for support-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Nobody's coming for a while if it keeps up like this. Not in a boat, not in a plane- Donna looks at the rain pouring down outside-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It doesn't look so bad. They'll be getting the rescue team together: by now.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: EXT SHORE - DAY “448 RAIN blasts the signal fire pile, no longer even smolderi as high seas blast the rocks in the BG- .

dialogues.speaker: EXT WOODS
dialogues.text: RAIN beats down-

dialogues.speaker: EXT HOUSE
dialogues.text: We see the little lean-to house through a torrential DOWN

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE 121
dialogues.text: Noelle, wearing Smilin Jack's jacket, sleeps by the fire, WHEEZING in the early stages of pneumonia. Donna crouches the opening to the outside, watching the RAIN blast down-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's got to stop sometime.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Humor me, okay?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It was worse yesterday. And the day before.. We just have to hang on.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: The signal fire is probably out-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: As soon as it clears we'll get it going again. Donna crosses to Noelle, feels her forehead, worried. She sees something, digs- comes up with the diary. Joe watche as she opens the clasp, starts to thumb through the pages She frowns-  122 6/4/98 113.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's blank.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: The pages are blank after the first couple entries. The foxes haven't even had their babies yet. They both look at Noelle. Donna closes the diary, clasps shut, carefully replaces it-

dialogues.speaker: INT HOUSE
dialogues.text: We start on the FIRE, a bit smoky but comforting against sound of the RAIN still .pelting down. We PAN to Noelle, wrapped in as many layers as possible, eyes bright with f as she ceremoniously opens the diary and fixes Joe and Do with a look. She reads softly-

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: We won't bury her on the island. She made me promise. She whispered it, hissed it in my ear one night when she was laying hard beside me in bed. "Promise me". She wouldn't listen to anything else. We had come back from looking for deer, Papa and me, signs at the salt lick but nothing to shoot at. I was putting his rifle back where he hid it in the shed roof when I heard him cry out. He wouldn't let me in at first, though I hollered and struck at the door. He opened up when he'd got her down on the table, but I saw the black mark around her neck where the cord was. The fire had gone out, so our breath was showing, Papa and me, and it was like long white sighs of grief in the room and her mouth open and hair crispy to the touch. We wrapped her in the afghan, then I got the fire going while Papa just sat. Nothing to say. Later we found the note and she told how the animals were Satan's handmaidens, how their sharp little eyes would not give her peace so she killed them and threw the axe in the woods. 'We have looked into ourselves,' she wrote, ‘and what is there condemns us.' We'll take her off the island come first thaw. If Fox comes then, padding through the trees to be my mate, He will find us gone.  123 6/4/98 114. Donna and Noelle lock eyes for a long moment -

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: That's it?

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: That's it. The last entry. Donna nods-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Litte Anne Marie there. Her mother didn't love her enough to stick around.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: She was crazy.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She still left her daughter in the lurch. I'd never do that. No matter what. Donna and Noelle stare at each other. Noelle fights not t ery-

dialogues.speaker: INIT HOUSE
dialogues.text: Joe sits by the fire. Donna SINGS softly as she holds Noe asleep on her lap. She stops, strokes her daughter's’ hai

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: I kind of look forward to her being sick. It's the only time she lets me hold her anymore.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's some kind of fever.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's in her lungs. We have to get her out of here. (sad) You really think he might bring people to, kill us? JOE (nods) I hope I'm wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: If we- when we get back- I've still got these tour dates up north. I'd only be gone for-  124 6/4/98 115.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She could stay with me. Donna looks at him-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You both could- if you wanted-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: You're not sick of us?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If you're not sick of me. DONNA (considers) Hey- there's nobody in the world I'd rather be stranded in desperate circumstances with. Really. But we should- take our time with the furniture-moving part. We come with a lot of baggage-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hey-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: She pretends not to, but she gets her hopes up for me. You know? And when it doesn't work out---

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I'll take care of her. They look at each other, closing the deal-

dialogues.speaker: EXT SHORE
dialogues.text: A clear morning, finally. Calm water. The signal fire is burning again-~

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: Donna, Joe and Noelle stand at the edge of the woods, bod half behind tree trunks, watching the sky. Noelle is shivering, wearing Smilin Jack's jacket. Donna sees, poin

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: There it is.

dialogues.speaker: SKY, PLANE
dialogues.text: A float PLANE is a tiny dot in the sky at first. We hear distant BUZZ-

dialogues.speaker: TRIO
dialogues.text: Watching with a mixture of fear and hope-  125 126 6/4/98 116.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: It's bigger.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Room for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: NOELLE
dialogues.text: Or those men. Donna looks at her daughter, then at Joe. The BUZZ of the plane gets louder. Donna looks to the plane, approaching, and makes up her mind-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: The hell with it. I'm not staying here. She steps out into the open-

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Donna-

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Donna marches out and stands in front of the signal fire-

dialogues.speaker: INT PLANE
dialogues.text: Still quite a ways off, we see a small figure standing in front of a tiny fire- EXT. SHORE - DONNA ‘ 126 Donna tries to keep a firm jaw as she watches the plane-

dialogues.speaker: WOODS
dialogues.text: Joe hesitates, then starts out for her-

dialogues.speaker: SHORE
dialogues.text: Joe steps up by Donna. They exchange an uneasy look, then look back to the plane. The BUZZING gets louder. Noelle appears between them, shivering. Donna puts her arm aroun her. Joe does the same. The lost family watch the approaching plane as the BUZZING gets louder. We SLOWLY F TO WHITE. The BUZZING gets louder, louder, louder-
